div.p: Greetings. I received your letters today through Froschauer and along with them, those which your brother transcribed and sent to me in your name. I thank you for these. In return, I am sending to your brother some notes, in which the names and numbers of the slain and captured are partly contained. Otherwise, we have nothing at all now, except that a rumor has been brought, which disturbs me, if it were true, which I cannot believe, that Adrien has defected to the opposing side. I await what more you will write and send through our courier, who has set out to you these days. I sent through him what the surviving captains have written to the 7 Cantons. I am now sending the session of Trent, which was held long ago, but which I have not yet seen published; I do not know if you have seen it. I pray that you send back the copy; for it is not mine. Many wonder why you trouble yourself so much in responding to Brenz, when he hardly seems worthy of a response. But I pray to the Lord, that He may supply you with long-lasting strength for the defense and protection of the truth. I can neither say nor have more now. I will send yours to Geneva today or tomorrow; for there are those here through whom I can conveniently do this.
All friends and brothers greet you, especially your father-in-law, mother, and the whole family.
I know that Steiger and Diesbach have received your letters, although I have not yet been able to speak with them today.
In Bern, January 18, which is my birthday, 1563. Your Johannes Haller.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the Zurich church, his honorable lord and dearest compatriot.
